results.title: Termite colony: a complex social organization
results.brief_description: A discussion of the polymorphic social organisation within an African termite colony, describing the unique roles of the queen, soldiers, and workers in the colony. Shows the care for the queen during the egg laying stage and the care for the young after the eggs hatch; the cultivation of a food supply for the colony; the defence of the colony by the soldiers; and the repair of the nest by the workers.

results.title: Terminus
results.creator_credit: Edgar H. Anstey, British Transport Films and John Schlesinger
results.brief_description: Impressions by John Schlesinger of a day in one London’s main railway stations - told with music, songs and half-hearted commentary. A historically significant account of Waterloo Station which has altered greatly to accommodate the Channel Tunnel trains. Music by Ron Grains. (Awards: British Film Academy Award - Best Documentary, Venice Golden Lion Awards)

results.title: Terminator 2: judgement day
results.creator_credit: Pacific Western, Lightstorm Entertainment and James Cameron
results.brief_description: Sequel to “Terminator”. The story resumes several years later in present day Los Angeles. A cybernetic assassin and bodyguard are sent back from the future. This time the target is John Connor (Edward Furlong), Sarah’s son. The story revolves around the conflict between two Terminators over the the boy’s life and ultimately the future of the human race. Arnold Schwarzenegger and Robert Patrick are suitably impressive and menacing as the two cyborgs, but in the words of James Cameron, the “real” terminator is Linda Hamilton as Sarah Connor. Her transformation from desperate prey, in the original film, to vigilante guerilla is rivetting. At the time of its release, “Terminator 2: Judgement Day” was the most expensive film ever made at a cost of $100 million. Fans of action adventure, mind-boggling special effects and wanton destruction will not be disappointed.

results.title: Terminal velocity
results.creator_credit: Hollywood Pictures, Buena Vista, Scott Kroopf, Tom Engelman and Deran Sarafian
results.brief_description: All is not what it seems in this action thriller starring Charlie Sheen as the hard-playing reckless skydiving teacher, Ditch Brodie, who finds himself asking questions when his beautiful new student Chris Morrow (Nastassja Kinski) mysteriously meets with a tragic accident on her first jump. Suspense and intrigue follow as Brodie accused of manslaughter is caught up in international espionage involving the Russian mafia. Cast includes James Gandolfini, Chris McDonald.

results.title: Teresa's story
results.creator_credit: Brent Productions, Wellington Community Law Centre and John Anderson
results.brief_description: This program was designed for use by schools and community groups, targets 12 to 17 year olds and people supporting them, and aims to inform about how the Child Protection system deals with reported abuse, the right of young people to personal safety and their legal rights under the Care and Protection Section of the Children, Young Persons and their Families Act, New Zealand.

results.title: Teresa
results.creator_credit: Francois de Lannurien and Gerard Vergez
results.brief_description:
Teresa, a middle aged women in financial strife has to take in a tenant. A young woman soon moves in. Lorenzo, Teresa’s estranged lover soon becomes infatuated by the young tenant. Awards: Grand Prix Feminin du Cinema, 1970.

Credits: Producer, Francois de Lannurien ; director, Gerard Vergez ; writers, Gerard Vergez, Michel Arnaud ; photography, Guy Fellous ; music, Vladimir Cosma.
Cast: Suzanne Flon, Robert Rimbaud, Anne Doat, Jeanne Allard.

results.title: Tent boxers (A)
results.creator_credit: Michael Riley and ABC-TV (Australia). Indigenous Program Unit
results.brief_description: Boxing is one sport that has produced some outstanding indigenous talent such as Lionel Rose, Tony Mundine and George Bracken. This documentary tells the story of the Tent Boxers who toured around Australia during the 1950’s and 1960’s as part of the Jimmy Sharman troupe. First-hand interviews by some of the Aboriginal tent boxers, including Roy Carroll and George Bracken, provide a detailed insight into the way these shows were run, the physical dangers, the control on and the lack of freedom experienced by the boxers and the exploitation of young Aboriginal men who found tent boxing to be a way of escaping unemployment. The paternalistic nature of the troupe’s organisers towards their boxers gave a feeling of family. However, the film shows both the positives and the negatives: Roy Carroll became Sydney’s first Aboriginal fight trainer and promoter and George Bracken, a champion of ringside boxing, but there was also an underlying attitude of racism by white Australians towards indigenous people, particularly during this period and some fights could get out of hand. “In 1971 promoters were required to have boxers and challengers medically examined before each fight and boxers were limited to one fight a week. This forced the travelling troupes out of business.”

results.title: Tenosinovitis
results.creator_credit: Women's Film Unit and Film Australia
results.brief_description: Female sufferers of tenosynovitis describe how they became injured. They discuss the way that their injuries have affected their lives within the workforce and at home, where often they must perform all the domestic duties.
results.description: Female sufferers of tenosynovitis describe how they became injured. They discuss the way that their injuries have affected their lives within the workforce and at home, where often they must perform all the domestic duties.
